abstract.text: Respond to the status codes returned by APNs servers.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

metadata.title: Handling error responses from Apple Push Notification service

inlineContent.text: Apple Push Notification service (APNs) provides a response to each request your server transmits. Each response contains a header with fields indicating the status of the response. If the request succeeded, the body of the response is empty. If an error occurred, the body contains a JSON dictionary with additional information about the error.
The table below describes the meaning of the keys in the header response for a failed request.
The HTTP status code. For a failed response the status code can be
The same value found in the
field of the request’s header. If you don’t specify an
field in your request, APNs creates a new
and returns it in this header.
The table below lists the possible values in the
There was an error with the certificate or with the provider’s authentication token.
The notification payload was too large.
The server received too many requests for the same device token.
The server is shutting down and unavailable.
The key below is found in the JSON dictionary for unsuccessful requests. The JSON data might also be included in a
The error code (specified as a string) indicating the reason for the failure. The table below lists possible values.
During testing, if you find that your test devices aren’t receiving push notifications sent by your provider server, refer to
The table below lists the possible error codes included in the reason key of a response’s JSON payload.
The feature isn’t enabled for this topic. Refer to
header isn’t properly encoded, or it’s greater than the allowed length.
header used in the request doesn’t exist.
The JSON Request payload contained an unrecognizable attribute.
The JSON Request payload is unparseable.
The push notification request didn’t include a notification payload.
attribute is set to an incorrect value. The only allowed value is
You have reached the maximum channel limit for your application. Delete channels that you no longer use.
is an invalid epoch timestamp. For channels with a
storage policy, you can only specify a
The topic is not allowed. Ensure that no push type suffix is added to the bundle ID.
The client certificate is for the wrong environment.
The bundle IDs parsed from your token or certificate don’t include the topic present in the path.
No certificate or JWT token provided.
The URL is invalid. Either the
The message payload is too large. For information about the allowed payload size, refer to
The request was throttled because too many requests were received.
The provider’s authentication token is being updated too often. Update the authentication token no more than once every 20 minutes.
The server is shutting down and unavailable.
The following code snippet shows a sample response when an error occurs.

abstract.text: Push user-facing notifications to the user’s device from a server, or generate them locally from your app.
Transmit your broadcast notification payload to Apple Push Notifications service (APNs).

doc://com.apple.usernotifications/docume.title: Sending broadcast push notification requests to APNs

abstract.text: Manage channels that your application uses for broadcast push notifications.

doc://com.apple.usernotifications/docume.title: Sending channel management requests to APNs

abstract.text: Generate notifications and push them to user devices.

doc://com.apple.usernotifications/docume.title: Setting up a remote notification server

abstract.text: Enable broadcast capability for Apple Push Notifications service (APNs).
Debug your server to send push notifications with device and broadcast push notifications.
